text: [ Induction of apoptosis in lymphocytes by glucocorticoids : between physiology and pharmacology ]
Glucocorticoids are physiological molecules that are also extensively used in clinics as anti-inflammatory , immunosuppressive or anti-tumoral agents .
Glucocorticoids can induce apoptosis on normal lymphoid cells and play a key role in the physiology of thymic selection .
In clinics these molecules are also used for their potencies in inducing apoptosis of malignant lymphoid cells .

Glucocorticoids are mediating their effects after binding to an intracellular receptor belonging to the steroid receptor superfamily : the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .
Once activated , the <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , can mediate his effects through direct binding on the DNA or via protein / protein interactions with transcription factors .

Depending on the type of lymphocytes , the mechanism of apoptosis induced by glucocorticoids fall roughly in two categories : induction of " death genes " by the activated <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( I kappa B , <extra_id_0> c-jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) or repression of survival factors ( AP-1 , <extra_id_0> c-Myc <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

In the case of thymic selection the mechanism is more subtle depending on the mutual repression of <extra_id_0> Nur77 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> GR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
